headline.main: The "Fallen Astronaut"

results.snippet: Among the artifacts of man left on the moon is a tiny aluminum statue called the "Fallen Astronaut," which lies in the dust near Hadley Rille. The smooth, abstract figure was placed in a small crater on Aug. 2, 1971, together with a plaque, as a...

byline.original: -- H.M

results.lead_paragraph: Among the artifacts of man left on the moon is a tiny aluminum statue called the "Fallen Astronaut," which lies in the dust near Hadley Rille. The smooth, abstract figure was placed in a small crater on Aug. 2, 1971, together with a plaque, as a small memorial to the 14 astronauts and cosmonauts who have been killed.

results.abstract: article on US astronauts who are no longer in space program notes that Apollo 15 crew members J B Irwin, A M Worden and D R Scott are being investigated by Justice Dept for allegedly receiving $7,000 each from W Ger dealer in return for carrying US postage stamps to moon; 398 envelopes containing stamps were transported to moon in pocket of Scott's spacesuit and were then sold to middleman in W Ger for total of $150,-000; Irwin, who has now become religious evangelist, illus

results.abstract: article on physiological effects of space travel notes Apollo astronauts have logged more than 8,600 man-hrs in space and that their experiences have shown that space travel does result in physiological changes that are far more subtle than had been imagined by scientists; finds physiological changes seem to be normal adaptations by body to conditions of life in space, but are tolerable in long run only if they level off at new equilibrium; some physiological changes experienced by Apollo astronauts during and after space flights discussed

results.abstract: Apollo 17 astronauts will receive less potassium in their diets than previous Apollo crews and close watch will be maintained over total fluid intake as part of efforts by physicians to deal with upset of body's chem imbalance, which is caused by weightlessness in space and which could result in physical ailments that could be fatal during taxing phases of moon mission; chem problems that have spurred interest of scientists are imbalance in body's supplies of sodium and potassium as well as fluctuations in heart rhythm during weightlessness; body's reaction to weightlessness is to increase fluid output with accompanying loss of potassium

headline.main: Apollo Crew to Get More Restricted Potassium Diet

results.snippet: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Dec. 6 -- The launching of Apollo 17 was temporarily delayed tonight -- just 30 seconds before the scheduled lift-off time -when trouble developed in the third stage of the Saturn 5 rocket.

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORDSpecial to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Dec. 6 -- The launching of Apollo 17 was temporarily delayed tonight -- just 30 seconds before the scheduled lift-off time -when trouble developed in the third stage of the Saturn 5 rocket.

results.abstract: Saturn 5 rocket with Apollo 17 spacecraft blasts off for moon from Cape Kennedy, Fla, at 12:33 AM on Dec 7; fiery exhaust turns night into day in delayed but spectacular beginning of last planned US lunar mission; explosive power of craft's exhaust sends tremors through soil for miles around Cape Kennedy and 'fills humid air with pounding thunderclaps'; estimated 500,000 spectators watch in awe as rocket arches into trajectory over Atlantic Ocean in 1st nighttime launching of manned US space mission; Pres Nixon sends crew message wishing them 'luck and Godspeed'; spacecraft achieves earth orbit; after 3 revolutions of earth, astronauts ignite 3d stage of Saturn rocket, sending craft out of earth orbit and toward moon; launching was delayed 2 hrs and 40 mins after Terminal Countdown Sequencer, computer system that monitors and controls all spacecraft operations during final 3 mins and 7 secs of countdown, indicated 30 secs before lift-off that liquid oxygen tank in 3d stage of Saturn 5 rocket had failed to pressurize according to sequence; pressurization is effected manually; highlights of mission revd; crew and lift-off of Saturn 5 illus

headline.main: A FLASH IN NIGHT; Computer Signal Halts Countdown With 30 Seconds to Go Apollo Launched on Last Mission to Moon After Delay

headline.main: Apollo 17

results.snippet: Apollo 17 and its three brave, highly trained astronauts finally blasted off last night after a tension-filled delay of over two hours. For days they will cruise through interplanetary space in their artificial cocoon; then two of the astronauts will...
results.lead_paragraph: Apollo 17 and its three brave, highly trained astronauts finally blasted off last night after a tension-filled delay of over two hours. For days they will cruise through interplanetary space in their artificial cocoon; then two of the astronauts will land on and explore an area of the moon never before visited by man while the third astronaut circles earth's natural satellite waiting for his comrades to rejoin him.

results.lead_paragraph: Eugene Andrew Cernan, the man who is to maneuver the Apollo 17 lunar module to a hoped-for gentle landing on the moon, was once flying a helicopter over water near Cape Kennedy when, as an investigative board later determined, he misjudged his altitude and slammed the craft into the water.

headline.main: Harrison Hagan Schmitt

results.abstract: Apollo 17 astronauts on Dec 9 fire main engine of command module when craft is 147,500 mi from earth, increasing velocity from 2,768 to 2,775 mph and altering angle of approach to moon; NASA says engine burn will compensate for time lost during launching; Capt Cernan and Dr Schmitt enter lunar module; check switch positions and circuit breakers and communications links with command module and antennas on earth in over-all test to determine how well lunar module withstood vibrations during launching; activate some of lunar module's control systems and unload lunar-landing equipment; rept 1 of 12 latches linking command and lunar module is not engaged, but NASA maintains problem is minor; conduct experiment in behavior of liquids under zero-gravity conditions and take star sightings to sharpen spacecraft's trajectory; transmit descriptions of weather conditions over much of earth; Dr Schmitt looks at earth and reflects on origin of life; wife of Comdr Evans and daughter of Capt Cernan illus; schematic diagram and itinerary of mission highlights

results.abstract: W Sullivan article on experiments to be performed on surface of moon by Apollo 17 astronauts notes most of scientific observations will be novel since previous policy, under which experiments were conducted at different sites with identical instruments, has been discarded in favor of independent tests, which will employ completely different instruments; Cernan and Schmitt will conduct experiments to determine direction of travel, speed and mass of micrometeorites hitting moon, and will seek evidence of lunar gravity waves; will also record moonquakes, changes in moon's shape as it responds to earth's gravity, measure radiation from lunar soil taken from different depths, probe subsurface soil layers with radio transmitter, deploy gravimeter to delineate shape of bedrock formations underlying Apollo 17 landing site, and will conduct seismic profiling experiment to determine existence and depth of rock layer beneath landing area; planned experiments detailed; illus of instruments to be left on lunar surface by astronauts and descriptions of their functions

results.abstract: scientists reptdly are eagerly awaiting samples of orange soil discovered by Apollo 17 astronauts Dr H H Schmitt and Capt E A Cernan during excursion to 7,000-ft South Massif, 4 mi southwest of landing site, on 2d lunar walk; strongly suspect samples derive colors from action of erupting gases in 'throat' of volcanic vent; note landing area had been identified in advance as possible region of volcanic activity because of its dark halo; suggest that coloration resulted from venting of gases through lunar dust during final stages of volcanic activity, which contained enough water vapor and oxygen, or that soil may contain compounds of chlorine, sulphur, bromine and other typical vent products that are peculiar to vacuum environment of moon; ultraviolet scanner being carried in lunar orbit by command module indicates there is virtually no hydrogen in moon's atmosphere; gravity measurements by Cernan and Schmitt near massif indicate presence of deep mass of light rock, extending to mi or more beyond valley floor

results.abstract: Apollo 17 spacecraft with astronauts Cernan, Schmitt and Evans aboard is orbiting moon on Dec 15 and is surveying its surface with cameras and remote-sensing instruments; NASA flight controllers rept spacecraft is functioning normally and is ready to blast out of moon orbit within hrs for journey back to earth; Cernan and Schmitt stow rock samples gathered during lunar walks aboard command ship; crew repts seeing more orange-colored soil near rim of crater Sulpicius Gallus, area directly across plain from landing site in Taurus-Literow Valley where original discovery was made, during orbit 75 mi above Sea of Serenity; Evans maneuvers spacecraft in effort to point its scientific instruments advantageously for taking moon's temperature, searching for atmospheric gases, measuring surface elevations and probing subsurface features to depths of approximately 1 mi; scientific instruments, which are housed in rear of command module, comprise lunar sounder, infrared scanning radiometer, laser altimeter and far-ultraviolet spectrometer; NASA scientists rept instruments are functioning properly and are transmitting steady streams of data for analysis; instruments and their functions detailed

headline.main: End of A Great Adventure; Apollo

results.snippet: " That's one small step for a man, one giant leap for mankind." -- Neil A. Armstrong, as he became the first man to walk on the moon.

byline.original: -- WALTER SULLIVAN

results.lead_paragraph: " That's one small step for a man, one giant leap for mankind." -- Neil A. Armstrong, as he became the first man to walk on the moon.

results.abstract: NASA scientists rept on Dec 17 that remote-sensing instruments aboard Apollo 17 spacecraft have functioned normally and have transmitted a wealth of data on lunar temperatures, gravitational anomalies, subsurface features and atmospheric gases; say lunar sounder gathered data from 500-million points on lunar surface and that infrared radiometer returned 100-million measurements of moon's surface temperatures

headline.main: ASTRONAUT STEPS OUTSIDE APOLLO TO RETRIEVE FILM; Floats for 47 Minutes -Craft Will Splash Down in Pacific Tomorrow ASTRONAUT STEPS OUTSIDE APOLLO

results.snippet: HOUSTON, Dec. 17 -- Like the barnstorming wing walkers of yore, Comdr. Ronald E. Evans took a floating walk outside the Apollo 17 spacecraft today as it sped away from the moon and toward earth.

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORDSpecial to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, Dec. 17 -- Like the barnstorming wing walkers of yore, Comdr. Ronald E. Evans took a floating walk outside the Apollo 17 spacecraft today as it sped away from the moon and toward earth.

results.abstract: Apollo 17 astronaut Comdr Evans takes 47-min 'space walk' on Dec 17 while craft is 185,000 mi from earth; retrieves film from rear of command module that houses scientific instruments, which had been exposed during lunar orbit for mapping and ultraviolet spectrometry; illus; repts blistering of paint on spacecraft's exterior because of heat and formation of ice around nozzle of waste water dump valve; spacecraft reptdly has left moon's sphere of gravity and is accelerating under increasing pull of earth's influence; NASA flight controllers rept spacecraft is 'absolutely nominal' and that midcourse correction will not be necessary because of near-perfect trajectory; scientists at Manned Spacecraft Center rept remote-sensing instruments on Apollo 17 have worked properly and have transmitted wealth of information on lunar temperatures, gravitational anomalies, subsurface features and atmospheric gases; say lunar sounder gathered information at 500-million points on lunar surface and that infrared radiometer returned 100-million measurements on lunar surface temperatures; families of Cernan and Evans illus with former astronaut J L Swigert Jr watching telecast of space walk

headline.main: A Choral Toast for Brandt, 59

results.snippet: Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany celebrated his 59th birthday in Bonn. Helping Mr. Brandt celebrate were the Dusseldorf Male Choir and Vice Chancellor Walter Scheel. With a touch of humor, Mr. Scheel gave Mr. Brandt a coin minted during the...

byline.original: JAMES F. CLARITY

results.lead_paragraph: Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany celebrated his 59th birthday in Bonn. Helping Mr. Brandt celebrate were the Dusseldorf Male Choir and Vice Chancellor Walter Scheel. With a touch of humor, Mr. Scheel gave Mr. Brandt a coin minted during the 19-year joint rule in the 17th century of Dukes Rudolf August and Anton Ulrich.

results.abstract: Apollo 17 astronaut Dr Schmitt says he and Capt Cernan 'apparently did look at some of the oldest lunar rocks that it is possible to see,' during traverses on lunar surface, news conf aboard spacecraft on Dec 19; says oldest samples of lunar rock were coarse-grained breccias, which were discovered at base of mts in Taurus-Litterow Valley landing site, and that dark material covering much of area was 'apparently of relatively recent age'; holds orange-colored soil discovered at site does not 'necessarily have to be volcanic in origin'; says material resembles an 'alteration' associated with hot water, which on earth is usually the result of volcanic activity, and could be result of fluids seeping up from within lunar interior; news conf illus

headline.main: Astronaut to Visit Jordan

results.abstract: NY Times analysis of meaning of Apollo project finds 'a sense of loss' pervades US space community at end of program, 'a bewilderment' that comes from having achieved 'the impossible dream' and now 'being left with...a gnawing feeling' that all the effort was not really appreciated; speculates that reasons for confusion over significance of Apollo project probably resides in fact that it was out of step with the times since 'for all its vaunted tech, it was somewhat old-fashioned, a reflection of America's past more than of America's present'; contends Apollo was an expression of faith in the value of scientific discovery in a time of reaction against science, and was an act of 'can-do optimism,' of a belief in progress in a time of reigning pessimism; maintains Apollo was work of a dedicated team pursuing a well-defined goal in a time of bitter confusion over natl purpose, but a 'success rising above so much failure'

headline.main: Meaning of Apollo: The Future Will Decide

results.snippet: HOUSTON, Dec. 20 -- A sense of loss pervades the space community on the day after Apollo. It is the bewilderment that comes from having achieved "the impossible dream" -- a frequently used phrase here -- and now being left with nothing but memories...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORDSpecial to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, Dec. 20 -- A sense of loss pervades the space community on the day after Apollo. It is the bewilderment that comes from having achieved "the impossible dream" -- a frequently used phrase here -- and now being left with nothing but memories and a gnawing feeling that all the effort was not really appreciated. headline.main: For Many, Life Will Never Be The Same; After Apollo

results.snippet: HOUSTON -- Every other ending in space flight has been the prelude to a greater beginning. After the Mercury program, involving the one-man capsules that pioneered earth orbit, came Gemini, the two-man vehicle that tested man and craft for moon...

byline.original: -- JOHN NOBLE WILFORD

results.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON -- Every other ending in space flight has been the prelude to a greater beginning. After the Mercury program, involving the one-man capsules that pioneered earth orbit, came Gemini, the two-man vehicle that tested man and craft for moon flight. After Gemini came Apollo and the reach for the moon.

results.abstract: Apollo 17 astronaut Dr H H Schmitt says on Dec 28 that orange-colored soil, which was retrieved from base of mt on lunar surface at Taurus-Litterow Valley landing site, does not look as bright as it did during discovery on moon

headline.main: Orange Moon Soil Looks Duller Now, Astronaut Asserts

results.snippet: HOUSTON, Dec. 28 (UPI) -The first scientist to land on the moon studied the "most fantastic collection" of rocks gathered by Apollo astronauts yesterday and said the orange soil did not look as bright as it had when he kicked it around on the moon.
results.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, Dec. 28 (UPI) -The first scientist to land on the moon studied the "most fantastic collection" of rocks gathered by Apollo astronauts yesterday and said the orange soil did not look as bright as it had when he kicked it around on the moon.
